The horror genre has been chosen carefully for this film because it helps conveying the message better. it allows you to feel uncomfortable and disgusted in view of those difficult issues.  in short the film is an outstanding film with terrific performances and script. i was really impressed.

STRAP IN MOTHERFUCKERS. WHITE BOY'S GOIN' ON A FUCKING RANT.  I'll be honest. With as much praise as this movie has gotten, I was expecting a smarter film. All I really got was a movie about black people vs evil white people. A very good one, mind you, but I expected more from something with THIS much acclaim. It's such a well-made film, which makes its ridiculous portrayal of white people stand out like a sore thumb.   Now, when I say "ridiculous portrayal", I don't mean that they made them the villains. It's a horror movie about a cult of white people, I get it. I'm talking how every single, solitary white individual in this film is either a psychotic monster, a textbook caricature of a wealthy socialite, or both. You've got this very well-acted and realistic portrayal of a black man with Chris, and yet you also have what basically amounts to a bunch of over-the-top cartoons of white people. It's fine when the family drops the act and no longer has to pretend like they're not crazy, but it doesn't really mean much when every white person beforehand acted as creepy and "innocently insensitive" as possible.  Honestly, I wouldn't be complaining if there had been at least ONE sympathetic, or just plain realistic, white character. Just ONE. One white character who wasn't evil, or who wasn't constantly making backhanded racist compliments because "oh boy white people are just SOOOOOOOOO awkward around black people ALL THE TIME"! But no. No, they just had every single white person be an inhuman monster. However, what I found most absurd, even harmful, is that the movie in no way, shape, or form makes an attempt to imply that all white people aren't like this, that they are not all in some way bad people. There is not one positive portrayal of a caucasian in this film, and I think the fact that nobody seems bothered by that is bullshit.   And before any of you start in, let me make one thing abundantly clear. I'm not a fucking idiot. I am a aware that this is a film. I am aware that it is a horror film. I am aware that it is meant to be pretty tongue-in-cheek, and that the over-the-top portrayal of white society was intentionally over-the-top. This is a very well-made suspense film created primarily for the purposes of entertainment which cleverly and creatively subverts many common horror-movie tropes. I do not believe that Jordan Peele's views on white people as seen in this film are meant to be taken literally, and I do not believe he is trying to tell black people that all whites are dangerous psychos who want to take their fucking bodies. The fact is, however, that the negative implications are there, they are rather blatant, and anyone who attempts to deny this is a fool.  I should wrap this up before I start to ramble. That would be embarrassing. I'll leave you with this: imagine for a minute if the race roles in this movie had been reversed. Imagine if a white man had gone to visit his black girlfriend's family, only to discover that they belong to a cult of psychopaths who want to put their brains in the bodies of white people because they believed society favors being white. Imagine if this Reverse Get Out had, like the real Get Out, not a single positive portrayal of it's antagonist race, if every black person was a villain in some way. Imagine if THAT was what Get Out was. There would have protests on every forum, any any theater that showed it would be mobbed with crowds of angry people. Once again, anyone who tries to claim this would not be the case is either ignorant or just arguing for argument's sake because they don't like what I'm saying.   I believe that this was an excellent film, and that it deserves much of the praise it has received. I also believe that there are aspects of it that people have deliberately ignored. There are things in this film which are inaccurate, inflammatory, and yes, even racist, but nobody would ever dare talk about them for fear of being called a racist themselves. This was a movie that should have been much better-written than it was, and which needed to be needed to be far less black-and-white (pun fully intended) than it was.

Get Out has been seen by some commentators as a satire on the dynamics of so-called "West Wing liberals",[18] who consider themselves to be allies to movements against racism, yet do more harm than good. Lanre Bakare of The Guardian commented on this, saying, "The villains here aren't southern rednecks or neo-Nazi skinheads, or the so-called 'alt-right'. They're middle-class white liberals. The kind of people who read this website. The kind of people who shop at Trader Joe's, donate to the ACLU and would have voted for Obama a third time if they could. Good people. Nice people. Your parents, probably. The thing Get Out does so well Ì¢‰âÂ‰ÛÏ and the thing that will rankle with some viewers Ì¢‰âÂ‰ÛÏ is to show how, however unintentionally, these same people can make life so hard and uncomfortable for black people. It exposes a liberal ignorance and hubris that has been allowed to fester. It's an attitude, an arrogance which in the film leads to a horrific final solution, but in reality leads to a complacency that is just as dangerous. (Wikipedia)

Minor spoiler. I suspected it was going to be some agenda pushing thing like the (Stanford Wives) or (Disturbing Behaviour) with virtually the same plot. Okay Disturbing Behaviour didn't really have much of an agenda but you know what I mean. But strangely enough the race part seems a little random. To anyone who doesn't want major spoilers stop reading now. To everyone else I'll continue. The plot is basically (The Skeleton Key) but with the races reversed. Which is where it gets weird. In (The Skeleton Key) they had a preference to possess people of their own race but due to circumstances the villains usually ended up possessing white people. In this film however every member of the white family have a preference for possessing black people. I can kind of imagine one of them having this preference and maybe another being apathetic about what race they possessed. But every family member is just weird and creepy. I suppose it is a horror film. But still the sheer statistical unlikelihood of the ENTIRE white family wanting to be black is weird and distracting.

While I love this movie, I hate how the trailer gives away so much, and I'm happy that I didn't watch the trailer until after I saw the movie. This movie was so great. It was so eerie and creepy and so scary, and tension filled, and filled with so much paranoia. I'd consider it more of a social thriller with horror elements, but it still managed to terrify me. From beginning to end, not only was it scary, but full of humor that works really well with the scares. Not only is this movie scary and funny, but it is also a terrific concept for a movie for this day in this era we are living in, through racism. To people who are concerned that this movie is racist, it's not racist, and you just need to chill out, because even the director said many comments about the movie that made him not sound racist, and he is already in an interracial relationship with a white woman, ironically. Which brings me to my next point, Jordan Peele gave an amazing directorial debut for his first motion picture. What a genius. This movie has so much to offer, including hidden messages on what world we are living in today, and things that could be happening that we don't know about or things that could happen in the near future. As a white man, with some black blood, I found this movie not racist, and I enjoyed it so, so much. Also, Daniel Kaluuya gave an amazing performance in this movie, and he plays his role of a smart and scared black man so well that it left me genuinely scared with him. I hope to see him in more movies from now on. Even the soundtrack, the score and some visual effects were so stunningly terrifying and fit so well in this type of movie. Caucasian participants (NÌ¢‰âÂ‰Û¡=Ì¢‰âÂ‰Û¡218) indicated examples of media portrayals of Black--White interracial relationships, attitudes toward Blacks, attitudes toward interracial relationships, degree of identification with Whites, and the degree to which Blacks are included in self-representations. Supporting our hypotheses, extended contact with Black--White relationships via media portrayals was associated with more positive attitudes toward Blacks and interracial relationships. These relationships were mediated by the degree to which Blacks are included in self-representations. This study furthers understanding of ECH by including representations of dyadic relationships and suggests an avenue for the creation of interventions for improving attitudes toward interracial relationships.

A lot of people don't get the meta humor with this film. Jordan Peele of Key and Peele is mixed and grew up in a wealthy neighborhood, going to private schools. The crux of their jokes (as Peele is black but adopted by a white couple) is their conflicting identities of growing up in privileged households but feeling like outcasts by their mixed ethnicity. Their jokes hit on white and black ignorance in the same way Chappelle did a decade earlier. In particular they call out elite whites who lord above poor whites as if they're better but their reach and power makes them more dangerous. Shoot, even alt-right outlets like Breitbart have latched onto this film saying it's brilliant so subversive.  So maybe give it a chance before you condemn it.

Everyone this is just a movie. It is a fictional scenario not to be taken seriously. This movie is about how the system of slavery was built on and continued by control of the mind rather than the bod. In addition to the bodily torture that slaves endured, another reason why they did not overpower masters in places where the slave population outnumbered the white population is because the institution was equally (possibly more) psychological as it was physical.  In the movie there is a slave market operation in the form of an auction that operates in the white girlfriend's home.The mom hypnotizes them, the dad sells them off. They are not playing bingo, they are betting on the "merchandise" who we see depicted to be the boyfriend in the picture behind the girlfriend's father who is acting as an auctioneer. This means the protagonist has been hypnotized and ready to sell. We know this when we see him sink from the bed into a chair and the narrator says "A mind is a terrible thing to waste." He is sinking into a deep sleep, out of the world he knows, and into his own mind where a white doctor with tools attempts to operate on him, personifying manipulation and how it works on the mind while the person is trapped and helpless. It's a cinematic horror rendition of the horrors imposed on the African Slaves mind and a horror that continues. No coincidence that this movie comes out during black history month. This movie was not created to demonize whites. It was created to be a visual dramatization of the psychological control black Americans have been under since the founding of this nation. Because this form of horror is not as apparent as physical, bodily horrors, it is gone unnoticed by those privileged enough to never have experienced it. This movie brings into light the agony black people experienced for centuries -- the kind that was never outlawed.  In other words it was created to inform and not divide. There is no need to be hateful or guarded against this movie. It is a film with historical roots. It is important to go back and study history every now and then and a movie which provokes thought is a fun way to do it. In other words it is just a movie.

Hear me out and then rewatch the trailer.  This movie is about how the institution of slavery was built on and perpetuated by control of the mind. In addition to the bodily torture that slaves endured, another reason why they did not overpower masters in places where the slave population outnumbered the white population is because the institution was equally (possibly more) psychological as it was physical. Slaves were brainwashed to believe that they were inferior and incapable. I feel there is a misconception in the United States that because black slaves were physically freed by law hundreds of years ago that there is nothing that should be keeping black Americans back in society - they are no longer bound to second class citizenship. Additionally, by this same mentality, any struggle the black community faces is its own doing and anything contrary is "all in their minds." Some delusional bigots go so far as to claim any shortcomings is enbeded in DNA and culture. What this narrow idea fails to recognize is how deeply embedded psychological oppression is and how it carries on for generations as it perpetuates in a society that is systematically racist and exclusive. Back to the movie...This is a small town (as opposed to the big city the cop refernces) that is clearly prejudiced. This is established by the officer asking for ID from the black passenger and not the white driver. This is a modern day example of one of the many forms of segregation that has survived in the U.S.  The "help" is clearly being hypnotized and brainwashed by the homeowners who represent slaveowners. We know this not just by the strange way they behave and the distant stare in their eyes, but the mother of the white girlfriend admits to performing hypnosis. She has hypnotized the lady and gentleman who now act as a gardener and housekeeper (both essentially enslaved). I argue that the father offers to hypnotize the young man out of smoking as a means to get into his mind. When he refuses they take more drastic measures... See, I think this town brings in black men and women from the nearby city, hypnotizes them, brainwashes them, and controls them to work for free. That's why the black men who visit that town go missing. The young man by the drinks with the blank look in his eye shook the wrist of the black boyfriend (instead of returning the "pound") suggests that this young man lives in another time...he's not familiar with modern greetings and dresses a bit old fashioned for his age. When the protagonist realizes the strange guy is possibly one of the missing black men ( or maybe he just wants to prove to his buddy that there are other black young people in the town) he snaps a picture, setting off the flash, and breaking the spell/hypnosis the guy is under.Ìâ  While without context it may appear that he began yelling "GET OUT" as a threat, it was A) really a warning for the protagonist to get the hell out of that town before they get to him and/or B) a plea for the manipulators to get out of his head. This is further supported by the gardener who, arguably, was attempting to run away in that strange scene where he was running towards/past the protagonist. He is trapped also and attempting to escape slavery. There is a slave market operation in the form of an auction that operates in the white girlfriend's home.The mom hypnotizes them, the dad sells them off (not sure if the girlfriend lures them in). They are not playing bingo, they are betting on the "merchandise" who we see depicted to be the boyfriend in the picture behind the girlfriend's father who is acting as an auctioneer. This means the protagonist has been hypnotized and ready to sell. We know this when we see him sink from the bed into a chair and the narrator says "A mind is a terrible thing to waste." He is sinking into a deep sleep, out of the world he knows, and into his own mind where a white doctor with tools attempts to operate on him, personifying manipulation and how it works on the mind while the person is trapped and helpless. It's a cinematic horror rendition of the horrors imposed on the African Slaves mind and a horror that continues. No coincidence that this movie comes out during black history month. This movie was not created to demonize whites. It was created to be a visual dramatization of the psychological control black Americans have been under since the founding of this nation. Because this form of horror is not as apparent as physical, bodily horrors, it is gone unnoticed by those privileged enough to never have experienced it. This movie brings into light the agony black people experienced for centuries -- the kind that was never outlawed.  I'm from Brazil and my English isn't perfect. I enjoys studying U.S. history, law, and sociology. These are just my observations and opinions. I might be complete overthinking it.

Short Version: Cultural and racial unity is what the country should strive for, but instead movies like this threaten to destroy it.  This movie is complete trash. If this is a horror movie, there should be no reason for politics to even play a role in the plot. All it's doing is encouraging racism towards white people. In American history, slavery did exist, but recently (newsflash) it was abolished. Some white people are racist and some black people are racist and all each race does is find pathetic stereotypes towards the other race in order to shame and humiliate them. This society is meant to be a melting pot of all races for freedom and equality, but when a person or group of people from one race harms another, that race is suddenly labeled and stereotyped. Not every Middle Eastern immigrant is a terrorist, not every black person is dangerous or on drugs, not every white person is privileged. As a white person myself, I hate people from my own race and people from other races because of who they are on the inside, not how they are portrayed. My girlfriend who is also white comes from a poor family who can barely manage to keep their house. While I was in school I worked with people from all ethnic, religious, and financial backgrounds and I really didn't care who they were as long as they were friendly. As for the terrorist argument, there have been both Middle Eastern and American terrorists. If this society wants to keep fueling the fire and pushing a wedge between groups of people, one day there won't even be a U.S.  Feel free to reply back, but I have said all there is needed to say on the matter.

Look. No one is denying that racism exists. In the world today, every race experiences some sort of oppression due to the still inherent beliefs of another race. White people are getting more upset about movies and media like this in recent times due to the fact that with absolute certainty, if the roles were reversed, riots would break out. People would die in the crossfire over a damn movie because it would be so upsetting. This is somewhat understandable because of the prior history between blacks and whites. In reality, it HASN'T been THAT long since blacks were slaves. It's ignorant to expect them to forgive, and forget when only a few generations ago they were PROPERTY. As a race, they still need more time to heal. Even now they're still recovering from those incredibly dark times. They're lashing out in america now, BECAUSE they have so much more freedom than they ever had before. It's a beautiful thing that they can even hold the protests, and meetings that they do after being oppressed for so long. (But there still has to be a line drawn somewhere. The peace deteriorating into violence is happening far too often.) Conversely though, it's ridiculous how often whites are demonized by the media as heartless monstrosities due to the actions of their ancestors. Media nowadays tries to convince white men that they are inherently racist, homophobic, sexist, and a multitude of other things simply for being white. If one were to make the same judgement conversely alluding to black men, whomever made said comment would become a social pariah. It's not ok to be racist towards anyone under any circumstance. But it needs to be acknowledged that it exists. It needs to be acknowledged that no singular race is to blame for the past. It needs to be understood that no race is without racism from, or towards them. Crackers can be racists. Monkeys can be racists. Chinks can be racists. Beaners can be racists. We're all fucking racist to a degree. But the demonization, and the overreactions need to stop. We all fucking suck. We're human. We're terrible. But we only have one planet. We're stuck together, and we need to learn to get the fuck along. That being said, movies like this aren't helping in such a sensitive period of time. It doesn't matter what race is being portrayed. Any sort of underlying allusion is going to set people off. There there will be people that get upset with those people for being upset. Then there will be people who get upset at the people getting upset at the people getting upset. It's a ridiculous loop of angry circlejerking. Until people can learn to no hate each other, and not be whiny little piss babies about every little thing, or sleight against them, shit like this isn't helping. Nor are the reactions TO the people being offended. I reiterate. An angry, racist, circlejerk. Not that it really fucking matters to anyone in the youtube comment section. I just wasted time of my life writing something that doesn't fucking matter.

Good Idea.  Bad timing.  All this movie is going to accomplish is making white people hate black people, and black people hate white people.   Movies like this don't work in the current social climate. 10-15 years ago this movie would have come off as an interesting way to explore ideas about race, class, etc. But it would have been seen as a suggestion on a new way of thinking; A way of saying "here is a thing presented in such a way, as to instigate new types of thought, and possible conversation." It would not have been considered demanding, though given the tone the movie seems to be going for, it would probably have come off as a bit over the top, but possibly in a productive way.  Not so in the current times. Movie like this come off as preach, demanding, and even hateful depending on the subject matter. The worst aspects of the movie will be taken grossly out of context, made larger than life in the public eye, and used as excuses for overall negativity, to put it lightly. In the current day, a movie like this seems to not only insist that what is shown is not a dramatization, but reality, and that in fact reality is probably much worse than what is being shown.  Movies like this just don't work right now. The debates it creates won't be informative, or constructive, or enlightened. they will be basic, useless, ironically "black and white", screaming matches about who hates who; who deserves what; what is and isn't racist, sexist, etc. Just a whole lot of people, shouting at each other, not saying anything.

The movie looks fine. The concept is interesting, it looks well enough acted, the production and effects look good, and the psychological/hypnosis angle of the plot gives it tons of room to do really unique things despite how much of the plot was shown in the trailer. Jordan Peele doesn't have anything noteworthy in terms of directing under his belt, nor does he have any real experience writing horror (that I'm aware of), but that makes me all the more interested to see how this turns out. I expect this movie to be successful and I'll probably go see it.  That being said, they picked a really shitty time to release it. I understand what they were trying to do. They used the current push of racial tension pumped through the media and the current social climate to make this controversial and give it attention. If you look at the discriminatory nature of the characters inside the bubble that is this movie, it's just a plot point used to push the story and it's events forward while setting up the overall concept in the context of horror. When you try to draw the real life parallels, however, it makes it seem like it's trying to make a political statement. Most of the people that aren't on board with this seem to dislike it because they perceive a narrative being shoved down their throat (which is understandable). That stigma is probably going to bite the producers in the ass in the long run and if they're not above exploiting racial tension for buzz, and I highly expect them to use it for the rest of the promotion of this movie as well as use it as an excuse if this movie doesn't turn out to be good, which will also lead to more negative press.  If you can separate this movie from the narrative being pushed in the real world (which you should since it's a work of fiction), I think it looks like a pretty unique combination of the psychological and slasher horror genres. If it still doesn't interest you, that's fine, but don't get up in arms over it for the wrong reasons because that's exactly what their marketing team wants.
